heading: dow tops 11k in late rally
subheading: the fed chief had frightened wall street with talk of declining unemployment fueling a rise in inflation. the latest labor stats say otherwise. investors go shopping. by david lazarus.
author: david lazarus
text: the dow jones industrial average blew past the 11000 mark again friday, boosted by unemployment numbers, suggesting that al "the assassin" greenspan had jumped the gun in warning of an "upside risk" of inflation.after seesawing back and forth for much of the session, the blue-chip index finally found its footing and rose 84.77 points to finish the week at 11031.59. the dow taunted investors by dancing back and forth across the 11000 line before settling for keeps above the bar -- just minutes ahead of the closing bell.tech stocks also showed a good deal more confidence, shaking off queasiness from recent spills and chills. the wired index gained 7.62 to 642.73, and the nasdaq composite index was 31.34 higher at 2503.62. the s&p 500 was up 12.95 at 1345.investors took heart as the us labor department released its closely watched non-farm payrolls report. about 234,000 jobs were created in april, and the unemployment rate increased ever so slightly to 4.3 percent from 4.2 percent a month before. hourly wages increased by a scant 3 cents.the stats were received by traders like lemonade on a hot summer day. greenspan had scared the bejesus out of everyone a day before with typically cryptic comments about how declining unemployment poses a greater threat of inflation, and how wage-derived inflation seems "inevitable."the latest numbers indicate that the g-man was being prematurely skittish on both counts."alan greenspan is trying to use psychology to police the market rather than fed action," said eugene peroni, research director at john nuveen & co. although traders were spooked by the fedmeister's comments, he added that this "won't be a lasting negative," and that few investors believe a hike in interest rates is in the cards, at least for the moment.adding to the upbeat sentiment was word form the business council, a grouping of active and retired ceos from 300 top companies, that the big cheeses of the corporate world feel that the worst of recent global economic turmoil "is now over," and that business likely will improve for the remainder of the year. these dudes should know.so ... anybody looking for a little ipo action? an outfit called latitude communications (latd), a maker of document-sharing software, climbed 15 percent to us$13.81 after debuting with 3 million shares starting at $12 apiece. the company -- goodness! -- has been profitable since late 1997, and earned more than $700,000 last year.not to worry, though. lunacy still reigns where the net's concerned.media metrix (mmxi), the leader in measuring traffic at high-volume web sites, more than doubled to $45.56 as it arrived with 3 million shares initially priced at $17 each. the company lost $7.5 million last year. and adforce (adfc), a provider of online advertising services, surged 100 percent to $29.94 after unleashing 4.5 million shares at an opening price of $15 a pop. it lost $5 million in the first quarter alone.netobjects (neto), an internet software unit of international business machines, barely kept pace. its stock rose just $1 to $13 as it began trading with 6 million shares starting at $12 apiece. with a track record as long as ibm's behind it, netobjects wasn't seen as the usual catnip by day traders, who prefer a nice, clean balance sheet to play on.the old guard on the net were led higher by etrade group and ameritrade after lehman brothers recommended that investors snap up both online brokers. etrade (egrp) rose $5.31 to $110.38, and ameritrade (amtd) was up $5.25 at $113.75.it's official: mci worldcom's bid to acquire wireless carrier nextel communications is kaput. "after reviewing the possibility of a combination with nextel ... mci worldcom has determined not to pursue a bid for the company at this time," mci said, while nextel insisted that it "already was turning its attention full time toward other matters." neither side said so, but it's understood that price was the sticking point.investors were relieved that all the will-they-or-won't-they anxiety is over. mci (wcom) gained $2.50 to $87.13, and nextel (nxtl) was $1.25 higher at $36.38. it should be interesting to see where mci looks next for potential acquisitions. there'd been rumors that the telco was set to go toe to toe with at&t for cable operator mediaone group, but the speculation never came to anything.another company that was rumored to be a player in the mediaone deal was america online (aol), which also ended up watching from the sidelines. aol's shares slipped $1.50 to $118.25, but the company plans to hold a little get-together with investors in 19 may, and can be expected to outline future initiatives for staying competitive in a broadband world."we continue to believe that aol's competitive position today is basically as strong as it was last week, before at&t agreed to acquire mediaone," said henry blodget, an analyst with merrill lynch. "it is hard to argue, however, that at&t's deals haven't created additional uncertainty about the future competitive landscape."in tech, qlogic (qlgc), a maker of computer-memory technology, jumped 19 percent to $90.06 after posting record earnings of 45 cents a share, topping estimates by a nickel. ibm (ibm) rose $8 to $217.25, providing much of the dow's momentum, and intel (intc) was up $1.25 at $60.94.lastly, some fun and games, just in time for the weekend. 3do (thdo) advanced 9 cents to $6.97 as it posted its first profitable quarter as a game publisher (as opposed to hardware maker), thanks to hot titles like might and magic and battle tanx. and multimedia games (mgam) soared 33 percent to $9 amid speculation of a pending takeover.the latter company doesn't make any battle tanx. it specializes in bingo. who says computer games are dangerous?
